ThingDef.label: Carapace Armor
ThingDef.description: Before the fall of the Coreworlds, the many armies of the Great Domain saw many servicemen divided into two groups, the Infantry and the Veterancy. While the Infantry was made up of various people from all walks of life, the Veterancy came from ancient nobility and were enhanced mechanically and biologically. This is the equipment of the Infantry, cheap and effective armor based on a plasteel framework with steel reinforcements to ensure an effective armor while being easy to produce compared to the Power Armor of the Veterancy. Its popularity remains after several centuries of usage

ThingDef.label: Heavy Carapace Armor
ThingDef.description: While Carapace Armor is better than flak vests and jackets, it does seem to lack a defense against charge weaponry and heavy munitions. An easier solution would be to equip all soldiers in the infantry with semi-powered armor but that is easier said than done. The end decision of this issue eventually became reinforcing the Carapace Armor with additional plates of plasteel to enhance its defensive abilities. The Heavy Carapace Armor was introduced during the Battle of Coldharbour after the Fall of the Great Domain to mixed success.

li.vanillaDesc: A reinforced variant of standard Carapace armor with additional plating for greater protection. The extra bulk makes it heavier and more resource-intensive to produce. Strong armor, but still not a true substitute for power armor.

ThingDef.label: Officer Carapace Armor
ThingDef.description: Carapace Armor comes in many shapes and sizes, this variant however was designed in the factories of the Deathworld of Fury. Despite the name, Fury is a highly organized society with a caste system which maintains a highborn nobility and a lowborn servile class. Often under siege by the Insectoid fleets, the Furian Guard is subject to the same stratification as their cities. As the Officers of the Furian Guard are found among the nobility, they have access to this specific armor. Reinforced with additional plasteel and adorned with gold filagree which offers both protection and proof of status.

li.loreDesc: Carapace Armor comes in many shapes and sizes... (same lore kept)
li.vanillaDesc: A higher-quality variant of carapace armor, produced with refined methods for greater durability without extra weight. Features gold inlay as a symbol of rank and authority. Solid protection, but more ceremonial than frontline gear.

ThingDef.label: Vanguard Carapace Armor
ThingDef.description: The most important part of any army is the ability to acquire intelligence on their enemies. The Vanguard Carapace Armor was designed on several planets though the most famous and its namesake would be by the Alexandrian Vanguard. During the First War of Alexandria against the Mechanoids, the most important factor in combat was speed. While not being heavy standard Carapace Armor is bulky and could be lightened. The Vanguard did so through removal of the shoulder plates and the “shaving” of certain areas until it only protected the chest of the wearer.

li.vanillaDesc: A lighter variant of carapace armor that sacrifices protection for mobility. Shoulder plating is removed and chest coverage reduced to cut weight. Favored by scouts who need speed and maneuverability over full defense.

ThingDef.label: Centurion Carapace Armor (Officer)
ThingDef.description: Based on the ancient warriors of Old Earth, the Centurions of the Holyworld of Sabbath are an elite force of warriors. Quick, decisive, and often brutal, the Centurions of Sabbath have served as the last line of defense for the Beaconist Holyworld. Often this armor is found in Rimworlds are from the Heralds of Sabbath, Centurion forces sent to recover Beaconist relics to further their quest for the source. As with the tradition of Centurions, they often serve as officers of a squad of lesser legionaries though the position is filled with veneration.

li.loreDesc: Based on the ancient warriors of Old Earth... (same lore kept)
li.vanillaDesc: A lighter officer carapace variant with removed shoulder plates to cut weight. Retains its gold inlay and status as a symbol of rank. Offers good protection with higher mobility, though the exposed shoulders make it a risky choice.

ThingDef.label: Carapace Greaves
ThingDef.description: The initial run of Carapace Armor often had protection for the thighs of soldiers but did not protect the leg from the knee down. This was chosen because of the need to keep soldiers mobile and moving fast. After decades of fighting Mechanoids and Insectoids in addition to humanity, the battle-smiths of the planet of Hastings created the Carapace Greaves. Built to the same standard of Carapace Armor, which allows protection but has the trade-off of heavy equipment slowing down soldiers, though the Dragonguard of Hastings preferred the heavy armor over nothing.

li.vanillaDesc: Armored greaves that protect the lower legs. Provide solid defense against melee and projectile strikes to the shins and feet. Add weight that slightly reduces mobility but complete the carapace armor set.

ThingDef.label: Carapace Gauntlets
ThingDef.description: Originally the Carapace Armor system did not include armor for hands. Many soldiers often complained about the lack of dexterity when handling their equipment, which left many of these gauntlets abandoned on the battlefields. Though when armies found themselves fighting the Insectoids during the War for Ramaal, many soldiers found the additional armor beneficial after seeing many of their allies dismembered. Bulky, cumbersome, and heavy, these gauntlets provide a level of protection that has kept many soldiers safe.
